statement.text: Hip disarticulation removes the entire lower extremity at the hip joint, reserved for patients with extensive proximal disease, failed AKA, or life-threatening infection, with low ambulatory potential and significant mortality.

explanation.intuition: This is the most extreme form of lower limb amputation - removing the entire leg at the hip. It's performed when disease or infection extends too far proximal for above-knee amputation, essentially as a life-saving procedure.
explanation.key_insight: Hip disarticulation is primarily a life-saving procedure rather than a rehabilitative one. Ambulatory prosthetic use is rare (<5% achieve functional ambulation). Most patients become wheelchair-dependent.
explanation.technical_details: Indications: proximal thigh gangrene/infection, failed AKA, extensive vascular disease, trauma. Technique: anterior racquet incision, divide muscles, ligate femoral vessels, disarticulate hip joint. Major structures: femoral artery/vein, sciatic nerve, gluteal muscles. Mortality: 30-50% perioperative (reflects sick patient population). Prosthetics: Canadian hip prosthesis - complex, rarely used successfully.

procedural_details.technique: Anterior racquet incision, muscle division, vessel ligation, joint disarticulation

primary_sources.title: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery

clinical_pearls: Mortality 30-50% - reflects extremely sick patient population
Consider when life-threatening infection extends to groin/proximal thigh
